column1: #text=I was riding my bike the other day when I noticed I was moving slowly , even though I was pedaling hard with a lot of effort .
#text=I stopped and looked at my front wheel and noticed that it was squished down against the pavement and was soft when I pressed it , instead of being firm and tough .
#text=It did n't have enough air in it to fill it up , like an old balloon .
#text=I took the bicycle home to my garage .
#text=Inside my garage was my bicycle tire pump .
#text=The pump would put air back into the tire .
#text=On my front tire , there was a tiny tube or straw that would let the air in when I used the pump .
#text=The pump also had a long tube with a tiny metal fastener on the end .
#text=I stuck the metal part into the tube so that it can blow air into my bicycle tire .
#text=The large metal cylinder part of the pump had a handle sticking out the top , which could be pulled out like a pogo stick , and two little metal feet on the bottom .
#text=I stood on the metal feet to keep the pump in place .
#text=Then I carefully pulled the handle out and pushed it back in .
#text=A dial on the pump showed me how much pressure I was putting into the pump by pushing on the handle , which then pushed the air in the tire .
#text=I heard it make a hissing noise .
#text=I kept pulling the handle out and pushing it back in , and noticed that the tire was getting bigger and bigger .
#text=Finally , after a few minutes , I pushed on the tire again .
#text=It was firm and ready to ride .
#text=I disconnected the pump and put it away .
#text=Then I went out to have fun on my bike again , with my tire working perfectly .
